body:
Hi, 
I figured out that I should run `git clone --recusrive` to clone the repo. The issue above no longer exists.
But another issue appears: 
It finds python3.8 on my host machine, but it could not find the python3.7 on the mounted .img in `/mnt/revpi2/usr/bin/python3`. Both python3.7 and numpy on the mounted path are not found. 
```

  Target "Python::Module" not found.

CMake Generate step failed.  Build files cannot be regenerated correctly.

```
I think the problem might be in my cmake command:
```
cmake \
-Donnxruntime_GCC_STATIC_CPP_RUNTIME=ON \
-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
-Dprotobuf_WITH_ZLIB=OFF \
-DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=/home/pengcheng/tool.cmake \
-Donnxruntime_ENABLE_PYTHON=ON \
-DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=/mnt/revpi2/usr/bin/python3 \
-Donnxruntime_BUILD_SHARED_LIB=OFF \
-Donnxruntime_DEV_MODE=OFF \
-DONNX_CUSTOM_PROTOC_EXECUTABLE=/home/pengcheng/protoc-3.17.3-linux-x86_64/bin/protoc \
"-DPYTHON_INCLUDE_DIR=/mnt/revpi2/usr/include;/mnt/revpi2/usr/include/python3.7m" \
-DNUMPY_INCLUDE_DIR=/mnt/revpi2/home/pi/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/numpy/core/include/numpy \
../cmake
```
Another question. [In this instruction](https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/how-to/build/inferencing#cross-compiling-on-linux), the raspbian .img downloaded from website does not have numpy installed. So I installed numpy in raspberry pi and make an image of it. Then I mounted the image on my host machine. Is that correct?

rename.from: Cmake failes while builiding onnxruntime python wheel for armv7l
rename.to: Cmake could not find python and numpy. Build python wheel for armv7l

body: Yes, it is correct. But looks like cmake can't find your python. Sorry I also don't know why.

> Yes, it is correct. But looks like cmake can't find your python. Sorry I also don't know why.

I found that the version I used above is v1.8.1. The CMakelist is different from v1.8.0. The above commands works fine with v1.8.0.

However, I meet another trouble. Python3 in `mnt/revpi2/usr/bin/python3` can not load shared libraries `libcrypt.so.1`.
I think this library refers to the library in mounted raspberry pi system?
I have installed python3-dev package on raspberry pi and I have excuted `sudo tar -C /mnt/pi -cf - . | sudo tar --transform 'flags=s;s,^/,/mnt/pi2/,' -xf -` before.
Do you know how to correct this?

For your reference, below is how we built the ARM64 package for 1.8.1:
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/rel-1.8.1/tools/ci_build/github/azure-pipelines/templates/py-packaging-stage.yml#L836

When you saw it can't find "Python::Module", you were using the code from the master branch, not 1.8 release.

The 1.8 branch should work good. (1.8.0 and 1.8.1)


And I set PYTHON_EXECUTABLE to the one in the host OS(/usr/bin/python3), not the ARM one.

I forgot one thing.  When you write the tool chain file, you should add
```
    SET(CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR xxx)
```

Replace the value with the output from `uname -m` of your device.

> I forgot one thing. When you write the tool chain file, you should add
> 
> ```
>     SET(CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR xxx)
> ```
> 
> Replace the value with the output from `uname -m` of your device.

Thank you so much!   I succeed in compiling, although I didn't add `SET(CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR xxx)` in the tool chain file.
